source.66dd8d94:
# Top 15 user location by number of tweets


import plotly.io as pio

pio.templates.default = "plotly_white"


data_plot = df.groupby('place_full_name')['screen_name'].count().reset_index()

data_plot = data_plot.sort_values(['screen_name'])

data_plot = data_plot.tail(15)

fig = px.bar(data_plot, x='place_full_name', y='screen_name',
             color='screen_name',labels={'screen_name':'Number of Screen Names'},
             title='Top 15 Screen Names places by number of tweets',
             height=600)
fig.show()

pio.templates.default = "simple_white"

data_plot_Top15_user = df.groupby('screen_name')['place_full_name'].count().reset_index()

data_plot_Top15_user = data_plot_Top15_user.sort_values(['place_full_name'])

data_plot_Top15_user = data_plot_Top15_user.tail(15)


fig = px.bar(data_plot_Top15_user, x='screen_name', y='place_full_name',color='place_full_name',
            labels={'screen_name':'Users','place_full_name':'Number of tweets'},
            title='Top 15 Screen Names by number of tweets',height=600)
fig.show()

source.5d438022:
# let us plot the Top location with number of users

list_of_country = df['place_full_name'].value_counts()[0:20]

country_count = pd.DataFrame(list_of_country).reset_index()

country_count = country_count.rename(columns={"index": "place_full_name",'place_full_name':'No. of tweets'})

#country_count.drop([3],axis=0,inplace=True)

ISO_Code = ['US','IN','GB','AU','CA','ZA','PH','NG','KE','CH','NG','ZA','IR','SG','HK','KE',
           'CH','CN','UG','ZA']

country_count["country_code"]= ISO_Code
source.6dd5133b:
import plotly.express as px


fig = px.choropleth(country_count, locations="country_code",
                    color="No. of tweets",
                    hover_name="place_full_name", 
                    color_continuous_scale=px.colors.sequential.Plasma,
                    title = "Top 20 countries by Number of users")
fig.show()
source.4c3bb1ef:
from wordcloud import WordCloud, STOPWORDS

# let us plot hastag

comment_words = '' 
stopwords = set(STOPWORDS) 
  
# iterate through the csv file 
for val in df['text']: 
      
    # typecaste each val to string 
    val = str(val) 
  
    # split the value 
    tokens = val.split() 
      
    # Converts each token into lowercase 
    for i in range(len(tokens)): 
        tokens[i] = tokens[i].lower() 
      
    comment_words += " ".join(tokens)+" "
  
wordcloud = WordCloud(width = 1800, height = 1200, 
                background_color ='white', 
                stopwords = stopwords, 
                min_font_size = 10).generate(comment_words) 
  
# plot the WordCloud image                        
plt.figure(figsize = (8, 8), facecolor = '#40e0d0') 
plt.imshow(wordcloud) 
plt.axis("off") 
plt.tight_layout(pad = 0) 
plt.title('text')  
plt.show()

#word cloud
from wordcloud import WordCloud, ImageColorGenerator
text = " ".join(str(each) for each in hungary.place_full_name)
# Create and generate a word cloud image:
wordcloud = WordCloud(max_words=200,colormap='Set2', background_color="black").generate(text)
plt.figure(figsize=(10,6))
plt.figure(figsize=(15,10))
# Display the generated image:
plt.imshow(wordcloud, interpolation='Bilinear')
plt.axis("off")
plt.figure(1,figsize=(12, 12))
plt.show()

source.4b879b0b:
#Hungary Covid-19. August 24 - 09:15 AM: Number of infections increases to 5,191

The number of confirmed people infected with the coronavirus in Hungary now stands at 5,191. In compulsory home quarantine:7,917. Recovered: 3,695. Deceased: 613.

The total number of active COVID-19 cases is 883. The results show that 35 percent of those infected, 60 percent of the deceased, and 43 percent of those recovered live in Budapest. There are currently 59 patients hospitalized with the coronavirus, nine of whom are on ventilators.

August 24 - 09:03 AM: Chief Security Advisor: Stricter border controls will keep the coronavirus out

Hungary's chief security advisor said imposing border controls is the most effective way to prevent the import of the novel coronavirus from abroad.

Gyorgy Bakondi told public news channel M1 that the epidemic is worsening across Europe, including countries close to Hungary and this forces the government to tighten border restrictions from September.

Bakondi said these measures will not be new to the public, noting that similar restrictions were imposed during the height of the epidemic in the spring. “The important thing is for Hungarians to be aware that such a plan is in the works and for them to arrange their trips in a way that they comply with tightened border controls which could create difficult situations when one is leaving or entering the country,” 

The government will do everything in its power to keep the virus outside the country and prevent its import from abroad either by Hungarians or foreigners, he added. To this end, border controls, screenings and quarantine rules must be tightened and the government must review its classification of countries according to the prevalence of Covid-19. http://abouthungary.hu/news-in-brief/coronavirus-heres-the-latest/

source.aff774a3:
#Could tuberculosis DNA recovered from a 200 year-old mummy provide doctors with new ways to treat the disease?

By SARAH GRIFFITHS -PUBLISHED: 15:16 BST, 22 July 2013

The DNA sample was taken from a lung from a mummified Hungarian woman called Terézia Hausmann, who died aged 28 in December 1797

The results revealed that the woman was infected with two different strains of TB bacterium. Findings provide chance to study pathogens from a time before antibiotics. 

British scientists have recovered tuberculosis DNA from a 200 year-old Hungarian mummy. University of Warwick researchers have recovered tuberculosis (TB) genomes from the lung tissue of the mummy using a technique known as metagenomics.

Scientists have previously performed molecular analyses of a chest sample taken from the mummy and deduced that her death was the result of TB. https://www.dailymail.co.uk/sciencetech/article-2373218/Could-tuberculosis-DNA-recovered-200-year-old-mummy-provide-doctors-new-ways-treat-disease.html

![](https://media.springernature.com/lw685/springer-static/image/art%3A10.1038%2Fncomms7717/MediaObjects/41467_2015_Article_BFncomms7717_Fig1_HTML.jpg?as=webp)(a) Location of Vác, Hungary. (b) Dominican church housing Vác mummies (©András Tumbász). (c) Mummified remains of Terézia Hausmann (©Hungarian Natural History Museum). (d) Record of Terézia Hausmann’s death (©Hungarian Natural History Museum). https://www.nature.com/articles/ncomms7717
